sec.p: In all cases with suspicion of criminal abuse and neglect by XBs/EBs, collection, transport, and toxicological analysis should take into account the procedures of quality, safety, and integrity in order to respect the chain of custody from point of collection to the forensic toxicology laboratory. An example of a chain of custody report was presented by the authors in a recent discussion on this topic (Dinis-Oliveira et al., 2010). This documentation is central to the demonstration that the evidence has remained intact, and not been adulterated, changed, mishandled, or misplaced in any way that would compromise its integrity. Properly maintained chain of custody documentation rules out any period of time in which a specimen may be left vulnerable to adulteration or tampering (Karch, 2008). Evidence ties together people, places, actions, and things that have important impact on circumstances surrounding events in which individuals are held legally accountable. The procedure also raises the issue of confidentiality and ethics where illegal activities may be involved (Wolff et al., 1999).

To date, a standardized protocol for sampling in suspected poisoning or XB-related intoxications has not yet been established, but there is a broad consensus that collection should be performed as early as possible after intoxication (Dinis-Oliveira et al., 2010). Sampling procedure, selection of specimens or quantity for toxicological analysis has to be case dependent (Plebani & Carraro, 1997), largely considering the case history, requests, legal aspects, and availability. Any specimen that was in contact with an XB is a potential candidate for toxicological investigations, at least, for qualitative analysis. Although toxicology testing can theoretically be performed on almost any specimen, it is usually limited to those for which there is an appropriate database available to help in the interpretation of the results or for which there is a validated method (Moffat et al., 2004). Blood, urine, and gastric content (namely gastric lavage fluid and vomitus) are normally used as specimens for XB analysis in living subjects. In postmortem toxicology investigations, specimens available can be numerous and variable (Skopp, 2004). They may range from relatively pure solutions of an XB to a putrefying specimen. Proper collection and preservation of postmortem specimens is critical, since there is usually no opportunity to go back for recollection of specimens after cremation. Peripheral and cardiac blood, urine, gastric content, and solid organs, particularly liver and kidney, are useful specimens to address almost all possibilities related to children intoxications. Specimens routinely collected at autopsy include peripheral and cardiac blood, urine, gastric content, and organs, particularly liver and kidney. Other specimens, such as vitreous humor, brain, lung, spleen, and skeletal muscle, should be collected only in specific circumstances (Dinis-Oliveira et al., 2010). Blood from peripheral sites should be obtained from femoral vein or artery and prior opening in the thorax and abdominal cavities (Skopp, 2004). Samples that may also be collected prior to organ dissection are urine, bile, cerebrospinal fluid or fluid from putrefactive blisters, hair, nails, and swabs from the orifices of the body or from the skin (Skopp, 2004). Organs are normally collected after evisceration. They provide one of the best and most useful specimens to assist in the interpretation of blood findings. XB detection in tissue specimens should be considered whenever highly lipophilic or preferably bound to tissue XBs are suspected to be involved in the intoxication. Organs may also be useful in cases with extended postmortem time period, namely in decomposed bodies and whenever body fluids are not available or difficult to obtain. A large amount of data for XB findings in tissue exists, primarily for liver and kidney and, to a lesser degree, brain and lung (Baselt, 2011). Plasma, serum, and blood are the ideal samples if quantitative measurements are needed. Urine is commonly used in qualitative analysis since relatively large volumes are usually available (especially antemortem) the concentrations of many XBs and their metabolites, tend to be higher than that found in blood, thereby facilitating detection. Gastric contents are also considered as useful specimens for the identification of an XB when the time after ingestion is short, since there are higher probabilities to contain large amounts of an unchanged form of an ingested XB. For the other specimens available, qualitative importance should also be considered, instead of quantitative analysis (Drummer, 2004). Particularly important in the field of drug facilitated sexual assault is the sample of hair of the victim in order to detect GHB (Kintz, Cirimele, Jamey, & Ludes, 2003; Kintz, Villain, & Ludes, 2004; Kintz, Villain, Pelissier, Cirimele, & Leonetti, 2005; Kintz, Villain, & Cirimele, 2008; Negrusz & Gaensslen, 2003).

A standard report format is very helpful and results should be reported in appropriate units, preferably written out in full to avoid confusion (e.g., between mU/L and μU/L), indicating the measurement uncertainty if desirable, with appropriate reference data or information to assist the requester in understanding their significance (Jickells & Negrusz, 2008). An example of a forensic toxicology report was recently presented by authors (Dinis-Oliveira et al., 2010). A negative result is not sufficient to establish that the XB is not implicated in an intoxication case. In addition, a positive qualitative analysis never solely provides conclusions of the involvement an XB in the intoxication but is only one of many pieces of evidence. For example, minute quantities of cyanide, arsenic, lead, and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) are regularly ingested from food sources or inhaled as environmental contaminants and retained by the human body, but in amounts that are insufficient to cause obvious deleterious effects (Klaassen, 2008). Ethanol represents another typical example since it is produced after death (Kugelberg & Jones, 2007). If the toxicological analysis indicates the presence of an illicit XB, then the environment in which the child lives should be supervised by the police.

sec.title: Good Practice to Prevent Intoxications in Children and Concluding Remarks
sec.p: Children explore the world around them. “the pica syndrome,” which means taking things to the mouth, is part of their normal behavior and growth process. The caregiver is responsible to secure the environment that surrounds children in order minimize all possible risks. This means, for instance, the need to improve XBs home safety storage and dispensing practices. In the past, not all manufacturers provided measuring devices with their products. Legislation of child-resistant packaging and increasing the level of enforcement reduces the incidence of poisonings (Franklin & Rodgers, 2008; Rodgers, 1996). Nevertheless, measuring devices are not standardized across the pharmaceutical industry (Dart et al., 2009). In addition, legislation is most effective when supported by educational activities. To ensure coordinated action, national plans for preventing poisoning need to be developed. Those should include child home visits, education on child poisoning prevention, dispensing medicines in nonlethal quantities, and establishing a national media campaign targeting child poisoning safety. Some important measures to reduce poisoning in children include:

list-item.p: avoiding administering medicines in the dark;
not exceeding the prescribed dose;

keeping medicines and other XBs/EBs (cleaning products, pesticides, paints, oil, solvents) out of reach of children. A paradigmatic intoxication results from unintentional ingestions of oral contraceptive pills by children, not only occurring in our country but all over the world (Lynch, McKay, & Murray, 2009). Authors reported that in almost 90% of cases the toddler independently removed the pills from the blister pack;
forgetting to close the medication bottle tightly and leaving the bottle without closing;

closing and storing containers immediately after use. Studies to understand how children access XBs suggest that the most vulnerable time is when the XBs are in use and therefore safe packaging alone cannot compensate for unsafe storage or use;

avoiding the use of rodenticides, mothballs, and other pesticides in areas accessible to children. Secure storage for XBs removes a larger portion of poisoning risk than parental supervision and may be an effective means of preventing poisoning injury;
avoiding the use of empty water or other consumables containers for storing other XBs/EBs. It is highly recommended to store them in their genuine packaging;
keeping alcohol in a safe place. It is important to remember that the perfumes, toilet waters, and shaving lotions can be alcoholic solutions;

being aware of the meaning of the symbols on the labels and reading the application instructions carefully and applying the products within the rules security, especially when using pesticides, corrosives, strip spots, and varnishes;
not having gas installations in the bathroom;
not having poisonous plants at home or in the garden;
not letting children eat berries or seeds of unknown plants;
not picking or cooking fresh mushrooms, if not distinguished accurately;
ensuring that that the child’s prescription is properly understood. If in doubt, should be clarified before leaving the office;
not administering drugs “ADULT USE” for children (Dart et al., 2009);
telling the doctor all the medications that are being administered to the child in order to review and approve the combined use with other XBs;

using the device dose (e.g., the dropper, measuring spoon or cup) that accompanies the medicine when administering the drug. Changing for other measure devices such as teaspoon, soup spoon, etc. can increase the risk of overdose (Dart et al., 2009);
avoiding taking medicines in front of children since they enjoy imitating adults. Younger children confuse drugs with candy, gum, and other sweets;
avoiding to have two or more caregivers responsible for administering child’s medicine (Dart et al., 2009);
ensuring that the XBs/EBs are kept enclosed and inaccessible, appropriately labeled in their original container and its opening is “child-proof.”

sec.p: To make a diagnosis of child abuse or neglect in any of its forms, one must be willing to consider the possibility that children are abused and neglected by those that are responsible for assuring their safety. Child poisoning by XBs/EBs is one of the most covert forms of maltreatment and should be considered to protect children. The work done by the Forensic Sciences and the Central Poisons professionals in recent years has made aware the public and health professionals of this possibility. Indeed, in a comparison between 14 countries that participated in both 2007 and 2009 evaluations, the average safety performance score to avoid intoxications in children increased 14.5% (MacKay & Vincenten, 2009). One study found concomitant child physical abuse in 20% of the children who had been intentionally poisoned (Dine & McGovern, 1982). Any child suspected of being intentionally or unintentionally poisoned resulting from serious endangerment or supervisory neglect should undergo a physical evaluation appropriate for age and circumstances and vice versa (Marcus, Ammermann, Bahro, & Schmidt, 1995). It is also clear that many of the familial and social risk factors to exposure children to XBs/EBs are the same as risk factors for physical abuse: abusive disciplinary measures, poverty, caregiver drug abuse, impulsive anger-driven actions, misinformed attempts at behavior modification, unrealistic developmental expectations, and a multiplicity of life, stressors.

Pitetti, Whitman, and Zaylor (2008) in a very interesting study showed a substantial number (8.4%) of children presenting to their emergency department with an apparent life-threatening event had a positive toxicology screen result. In particular, 4.7% of the children were found to have been given an over-the-counter cold medicine. The authors recommend that toxicology screens should be included as part of the routine evaluation of children who present with an apparent life-threatening event (Pitetti et al., 2008). The use of these medications is not recommended in young children, and Food and Drug Administration (FDA) dosing guidelines do not exist for children less than 2 years of age. Caregivers possess the mistaken notion that over-the-counter cold medications formulated for children are also safe for use in infants (Marinetti et al., 2005). In a subsequent comprehensive evaluation of pediatric fatalities associated with nonprescription cough and cold medications, authors observed that deaths in children appear to arise from product misuse rather than adverse effects resulting from recommended doses (Dart et al., 2009). Children less than 2 years of were the most commonly involved. Their small size may facilitate inadvertent administration of an overdose and it is also harder for young children than for older children to communicate emerging adverse effects to their caregiver.

To reduce the effects of poisonings on children, one prudent intervention could be to standardize investigations of pediatric victims of suspected abuse or neglect and to routinely include XBs/EBs screening, particularly medicines, in these investigations. In addition, a battery of XBs/EBs must be created and designed for that purpose and must be adapted to the reality of each country. The concept of child fatality teams was developed to address the recognized inadequacy of current systems in identifying the cause of unexpected death among children (Webster, Schnitzer, Jenny, Ewigman, & Alario, 2003). Children abused or neglected with XBs/EBs likely compose part of the hidden cases of child abuse, since many antemortem and postmortem examinations do not routinely include blood analysis. Providing a standardized evaluation of each pediatric death to the child fatality teams would increase the knowledge to this field and the routine investigation of child deaths would allow more accurate ascertainment of cases and perhaps identify additional risk factors. The cooperation between physicians and law enforcement and the need for law enforcement to be trained to recognize abuse and neglect of children by poisoning is mandatory. It is almost unknown what proportion of poisonings are suspected to be cases of abuse or neglect by hospital providers and/or reported to forensic services, neither the factors that influence the decision (Wood, Pecker, Russo, Henretig, & Christian, 2012). By reviewing contextual examples, we expect to further help medical doctors and law enforcement professionals to uncover these cases. In most police departments throughout the world, responding officers will be unaware or uneducated regarding the possibilities of abuse and neglect by poisonings. These issues would greatly benefit of medical personnel education to create a social movement that would lead to the recognition of these conditions in law, and the need to train law enforcement personnel to also recognize these risks.
